channel.title: Tutoriel mélangeur on
channel.description: Recent content in Tutoriel mélangeur on

item.title: Débuter avec Blender
item.description: Bonjour le monde! (Ajouter) # # not all of this is required, but just here for reference bl_info = { "name": "Hello World", # name of the add-on "author": "Blender developer", # name of the author "version": (1, 0), # version number for the add-on "blender": (2, 78, 0), # version of Blender the add-on is compatible with "location": "Space > Hello World", # where the user can find the add-on "description": "Greets something", # add-on description "warning": "Beta version", # whatever the user needs to be warned about "wiki_url": "", # documentation link "category": "Development", # add-on category } # the blender python module import bpy # this is just for convenience - could just use as bpy.

item.title: Initiation à la programmation dans Blender
item.description: Alors que la plupart du code source de Blender est écrit en C et C++, les extensions (add-ons) sont entièrement codées en Python. Blender est livré avec plus de 90 extensions installées, mais elles ne sont pas toutes activées par défaut. Les extensions Blender sont installées et activées via la fenêtre Préférences utilisateur (accessible via le menu Fichier ou avec le raccourci Ctrl + Alt + u). Bonjour le monde! (Ajouter) # # not all of this is required, but just here for reference bl_info = { "name": "Hello World", # name of the add-on "author": "Blender developer", # name of the author "version": (1, 0), # version number for the add-on "blender": (2, 78, 0), # version of Blender the add-on is compatible with "location": "Space > Hello World", # where the user can find the add-on "description": "Greets something", # add-on description "warning": "Beta version", # whatever the user needs to be warned about "wiki_url": "", # documentation link "category": "Development", # add-on category } # the blender python module import bpy # this is just for convenience - could just use as bpy.
